justification: The article notes that “dependence severity in humans, assessed by questionnaires or diagnostic criteria, is reliably associated with greater economic demand for drugs.”
Later the review states that individual differences in meaning in life were “partially mediated by indices of behavioural economic demand for alcohol derived from the Alcohol Purchase Task [101].”
construct: Relative drug value / economic demand for alcohol

justification: “In the concurrent choice task, participants make a choice between the drug and another reward … and the proportion of drug choices indexes the relative value of the drug versus the alternative reward [7,25].”
construct: Relative drug value / preferential drug choice

justification: The review explains that “presentation of drug related pictorial cues can increase drug choice … in the Pavlovian to Instrumental Transfer (PIT) procedure [36].”

Studies “measured the impact of drug devaluation on drug choice” by devaluing the outcome (satiety, taste adulteration, health warnings) and then testing choice in extinction to assess goal-directed versus habitual control.
construct: Goal-directed control of drug choice / sensitivity to drug devaluation

justification: For compulsion theory tests, “a cost was imposed on the drug choice … by increasing the number of responses needed, adding a delay, or increasing the value of the alternative … and the imposition of costs significantly reduced drug choice.”
construct: Sensitivity to costs on drug choice / compulsion

measured_by: negative mood induction concurrent choice task
justification: Regarding negative reinforcement theory, “drug choice was measured … then negative affect was induced … mood induction increased drug choice indicating that mood induction preferentially raised the value of the drug versus alternative reward.”
construct: Negative mood-induced drug choice / negative reinforcement
